THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: THE EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND.
div.p: The lecture which Professor Naville delivered on Monday evening last week at King's Collage on his fourteen years' work on the exploration of the great Hathor temples at Deir-el-Bahari was, says Mr. W. St Chad Bosoawen in the "Globe," an addres of great importance, not only on account of the archeologial matter, but also on account of the statements he made at the close as to the future plans of the Egyptian Exploration Fund. In his discourse the lecturer traced the progress of the work from the first commencement in 1898 to ita conclusion in 1907, and as the various stages of work were explained and the progress made illustrated by beautiful photographs, it was made clear what a great work had been accomplished. When Mariette gave up his work none of the greattemple was clear except the forecourt. The remains of the colonnades, the shrines, and the great alter were all hidden beneath tons of débris and landslips from the great western mountain. In addition, the remains of a Coptic monastery and village filled the portions above ground. This applied to the great temple built for Hatsbepsn by the architect Senmut The very existence of the older temple of the eleventh dynasty built by Mentuhetep, and the shrines of the Hathor Cow, one of the moat important discoveries ever made, on which Professor Naville waxed justly eloquent, was quite unsnspected. The work of the daring of the old temple belongs to years ago, in the present rapid progress of events; but there was one spécial point of interest which the lecturer referred to, and which was oertainly new. In the forecourt at the top of. the camp leading up from the plain was discovered an immense aquare altar, approached by steps. As the Egyptians did not use burnt offerings, its use was obscure, but Professor Naville showed that it resembled the great altars shown in the sculptures of Ankh-en Aten, at Tel-el- Amarna-which were piled with flowers, fruits, and various offerings of bread-cakes and other objects what time the King amended to offer his prayer to the noonday sun. When concluding his remarks on the exploration of the eighteenth dynasty temple, the lecturer showed a photograph of the absolutely cleared and partially restored building, and remarked, "that it was now in a much better condition than it had ever been sinoe the latter days of ths Egyptian Empire." For he said the Egyptians seldom or ever repaired a building, and more frequently when in partial decay it became a quarry for the workmen of later times. This had certainly been the fate of the older temple which preceded the building of the great queen. This work had occupied ten years. Passing now to the work on the older temple, buried benrath mounds of débris only partially natural, the lecturer brought out many most important points hitherto unknown, and especially interested his audience by exhibiting photographs of many of the sculptures retained at Cairo. Among these were a beautifnl painted portrait group of Mentuhetep and his negro queen. There is also another interesting group of one of the queens seated on a throne and receiving offerings of milk and cakes from attendants, while two waiting maids plait her hair and put the hairpins in it; certainly the earliest picture of an early breakfast. The king, Professor Naville said, was a polygamist, two wives being priestesses of Hathor, and they were buried in tombs in a courtyard behind the pyramid and beautifully decorated shrines erected in the colonnade above the tombs. The lecturer showed photographs of the very beautiful sarcophagus of Prinoea or Queen Kareit now at Cairo. Professor Naville devoted much time to the account of the discovery of the perfect shrine of the goddess Hathor, under the form of a cowwhich has been so often described. He mentions that careful rosearch had shown that there was a distinct association between the Hathor cow and the Apis bull. He had said that the peculiar markings on the body of the cow were not stars, as at first supposed, but leaves of a "four - leafed clover." Is this another proof of the antiquity of the shamrock? The most important point in the lecture was Professor Naville's exposition of the questions of the King's tomb. He showed most clearly that the great vaulted passage extending five hundred feet into the mountain could not be the tomb; but rather that great alabaster shrine, with its red granite roof, was, the chamber of the Ca, or double of the king, which was worshipped by the later kings Usertesen, Amenophis II., and others. He then proceedod to show that there was much evidence to identify tho tomb with that found in the south-west corner of the court by Lord Dufferin in 1889, which Dr. Naville cleared again, and in which he found a large uninscribed sarcophagus. In the course of the lecture, Professor Naville referred to the great help he had received from Mr. Hall, of the British Museum, and Mr. Aryton. The most important statement of all came at the conclusion of this interesting lecture. Mr. Naville, in speaking of the future work of the Egypt Exploration Fund, said that it was feared that the intended excavations at Abydos would have to be given up this season. The work on Deir-el-Bahari had costt so many thousands of pounds that unless subscriptions were forthcoming, a season's rest would be necessary. Surely there must be many who, while unable to visit Nile land, have had its best art and literature brought to them year after year by the Fund, who would contribute their guinea, or as much more as they like, in order that this should be remedied, and the twenty-five years work be continued.

div.head: A Faithless Husband
div.p: A Cairo Bey, rich and well known in the district, two years ago married an Israelite dancer named Latifa,and handsomely furnished for her a flat at Daher. Unhappily the fickle nature of the Bey was not proof against the blandishments of other artistes and his infidelity was the cause of many domestic squabbles. These only served to exasperate the husband with the result that, he completely deserted the home. On Monday morning, accompanied by a servant and several porters, he went to the house, and expressed his intention of taking away the household goods. This procedure the wife energetically opposed, and her cries soon brought several Israelites on the scene. One, a certain Leon Sion, interfered and a sharp combat followed, during which Leon Sion stabbed the servant with a knife. Meanwhile Mahmoud found means of informing the police, who, after considerable difficulty stopped the fray, and arrested Leon Sion, consigning him to the French Consulate, and transporting the wounded servant to the hospital, where he lies in a grave condition.

div.head:
GENEVA AS A RESORT
THE KHEDIVES VISIT
div.p: A correspondent writes from Geneva under date of the 31st ult:- The Khedive is here in Geneva and goes daily in his motor-car to the "Parc des Eaux Vives" to luncheon. His Highness is looking very well and apparently enjoying the change. The weather is very fine just now and Geneva as charming as ever. The Parc des Eaux Vives is only a quarter of an hour's walk along the shore of Lake Leinan, and is the fashionable resort daily during the summer for visitors to Geneva. The grounds are magnificent and the specimens of trees from different parts of the world to say nothing of the assortment of beautiful flowers and plants, are an endlçss source of enjoyment to all lovers of nature. There is a first class restaurant with an excellent cuisine. Tea and coffee are served at small tables in the park under the shelter of the trees. A fine orchestra plays daily and just now there is an open air theatre with performances every afternoon and evening, and plenty of scope for sport of all kinds.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MOTOR TRACTION CO.
div.p: At the adjourned extraordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Motor Traction Company, Limited, the resolution passed at the previous meeting that the proposal of an Enropean automobile manufacturer be accepted, whereby twenty new cars should be added to the company's stock was confirmed. The company have entered into a contract with Italo-Swizzera for five years for the maintenance of the cars in good condition and they have decided to commence immediately the construction of a garage on the property of the company by the Mahmoudieh canal.

div.head:
TRADE OF ALEXANDRIA
CONSULAR RREPORT
div.p: According to the report on the trade and commerce of Alexandria for the year 1906 by Mr. Greig, Acting Vice-Consul, which was presented to the Houses of Parliamnnt last week the total tonnage of ships which entered the Port of Alexandria during the year 1906 was 3,695,829 tons. In 1903 the total tonnage was 3,591,281. The increase during the last year, therefore, amounts to. 104,548 tons. Great as the increase is, it falls short of the average yearly increase of the five preceeding years, which was 243,132 tons. The tonnage of British, French and Italian shipping has decreased in almost identical proportions to the total tonnage of each, whereas Greek, German, Belgian, Austro-Hungarian, Danish and Ottoman shipping have increased in varying degrees. British shipping claims 1,473,087 tone, or 40 per cent of the total amount, and more than the Ottoman, Anstro-Hungarian, Italian and French shipping combined. , There has, nevertheless, been a decrease in British shipping of 48,792 tons as compared with the year 1905, whereas the average yearly increase during the five preceding years was 99,809 tons. Ottoman shipping, as in 1905, occupies the second place with 344,238 tons, or abont 9 per cent of the shipping of the port, representing an increase of 4,003 tons during the year. The average yearly increase during the five preceding years was 32,868 tons. Austro-Hungarian shipping, which occupied the fifth place in 1905, has risen above France and Italy to the third place with a total of 325,549 tons, or 9 per cent of the tonnage of the port, and has realised an increase of 14,881 tons, the average yearly increase for the five preceding years having been 12,357 tons. Italian shipping, which occupied the third place last year, now stands fourth, having yielded a place to Austria Hungary, with 323,942 tons, or 9 per cent of the shipping of the port, but has sustained a decrease of 8,342 tons. French shipping, which held the fourth place in 1905, having likewise been passed by Austra-Hungary, now stands fifth with 315,500 tons, or 9 per cent of the port, and has sustained a decreas of 9,629 tons as compared with 1906, the average yearly increase during the five preceding years having been 6,697 tons. German shipping holds the sixth place with 296,647 tons, or 8 per cent, of the total tonnage of the port as compared with 7 percent for 905 and 4 percent for 904. There has been an increase daring the past year of 34,976 tons, the average yearly increase during the five preceding years having been 40,442 tons. Greek shipping has risen from the eighth to the seventh place with a tonnage of 241,290 tons,or 6 percent of the tonnage of the port, as compared with 6 per cent for 1908, 4 per cent, for 1904, 3 per cent for 1908 and 2 percent in 1902. It has shown the considerable increase of 68,229 tons during the year, the average yearly increase during the five years preceding having been 18,510 tons. Russian shipping occupies the eighth place with 176,819 tons, or 5 per cent of the total shipping of the port. Belgian shipping has risen from the tenth to the ninth place with 63,628 tons, or 2 per cent of the tonnage of the port as compared with 1 per cent, in 1905. It has increased by the considerable amount of 29,267 tons during the past year, the average yearly increase for the five preceding years having been 2,083 tons. Danish shipping occupies the tenth place with 86,785 tons, as compared with 10,996 tons in 1900 and 23,052 tons in 1905. It has increased by 12,733 tons during the past year. Swedish and Norwegian shipping accounted for 32,736 and 25,871 tons, respectively. Their tonnage united' fall slightly short of their combined tonnage for 1905 Dutch shipping claims 15,634 tons, or 2,772 tons, more than in 1905. Roumanian shipping, unrepresented in 1905, contributed 12,811 tons. This is due to the service organised by the Rouinainian Maritime Company between Constanza and this port. Cyprus has during the past year been connected with Alexandria by a regular weekly mail service organised by the Limassol Steamship Company. A British maritime enterprise of the near future will be the service of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company between Marseilles and Alexandria A French company too, is said to be studying the question of a service from Dunkerque to Alexandria, touching possibly at Havre, Tangier, Oran, Algiers and Tonis.

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
COLLAPSE OF HOUSES.
div.p: The following questions concerning Egypt were asked and answered in the House of Commons on the 1st inst:- - Mr. John Robertson.- To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he can obtain an official statement of the number of buildings which have collapsed in Alexandria, Cairo and their environs within the last twelve months and the number of persona who have been thereby killed or injured. Sir E Grey.- I will enquire whether it is possible to obtain such a statement
CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.

Mr. John Robertson. - To ask the Secretary of state for Foreign Affairs whether in view of the fact that a number of houses in Cairo, near the Boghoa Paaha bridge, are without water supply, and that the Cairo Water Company, though repeatedly appealed to by the proprietors to meet their needs, has done nothing, he will suggest to the Egyptian Government the expediency of acting on the long-standing demand for the establishment of a Cairo municipality which can meet the requirements of the city. Sir E Grey. - I have no information on the particular point of the water supply and the contract with the Water Company. The question of the Municipality is a large and complicated one, with which I am not prepared to deal at present.
THE EDUCATON BUDGET

div.head:
AT THE ASSUAN DAM.
A WONDERFUL TRANSFORMATION.
div.p: Writing on the 19th inst. a.correspondent of "Pall Mall Gazette" says :- After an absence of quite eighteen months, I find myself again at Assuan, and, perforce, I have paid a visit to the Dam. I was exceedingly surprised at the transformation achieved on the west side of that marvellous structure. There is, as before very little to interest the eye on the drive out, which takes about thirty minutes from the time of leaving the hotel. The way leads across the sandy expanse which, broken here and there by overpoweringly high masses of sandstone and granite, causes the casual observer to imagine he is traversing the scene of some prehistoric volcanic upheaval But on a closer observation one sees in the formation and lay of the rocks that the right bank was in reality in former times the bed of a river, forming, in all probability, an outlet or tributary to the great inland sea, which is said by the geologists to have existed in the Sahara Desert At the reservoir there is quite a little colony. Where, a little over a year ago, only a relentless stretch of sand existed, there appear now numbers of neat and cool-looking buildings, standing in their own grounds, which are developing into produce-bearing and shade-providing gardens, affording a restful spot on which the eye, tired with the glare of the sun and the surrounding desert, can repose. These houses are the residences of the officials attached to the Dam, and of the engineers engaged on the new works. I entered one of them, and found it delightfully cool and comfortable, fitted with electric light and various conveniences with which the ordinary resident has to dispense. Some of the houses are excellently situated, standing at the summit of a series of terraces covered with the green plant, which out here cakes the place of turf. All this shows the richness of Egypt's soi!, and proves that with care and attention even the sand can be made fruitful. I do not mean that the sand alone can be transformed. What I intend to convey is the fact that with modem appliances and careful supervision no spot in Egypt need be barren. At present it is rather a critical time in Assuan from a hygienic point of view. It is the period of the green water, a stretch of water computed to be 500 miles in length, and containing a fungus whose colour gives the name to the water. This piece of water takes from seven to fourteen days to pass Assuan, aud during that time it is extremely dangerous to drink the water, As it brings on fever and colic. The smell is also most offensive. The residents at the Dam get the full benefit of this water, if one may call it benefit, and at present they do not feel over happy at their lot But in time all this will be a thing of the past, and I feel quite loth to leave what appears to be, and certainly is, a delighful spot to reside in

div.head:
THE GRANT TO LORD CROMER
SPEECHES IN PARLIAMENT
A CHORUS OF PRAISE
div.p: As announoed in our cable of the 31st ult the Royal Message recommending the grant of £50,000 to the . Earl of Cromer for his great services to Egypt was discussed in both houses of Parliament on Tuesday week. In the House of Lords, the Marquess of Ripon, (Lord Privy Seal).in moving that their lordships concur with the Commons in making the grant, said :- It is with great personal gratification that I rise to perform the duty which falls to my lot on this occasion. Lord Cromer's great services are so well known to your lordships and to his countrymen, that it would be out of place, and almost waste of time, if I were to go through any lengthy description of them now. The great success of Lord Cromer's administration in Egypt has afforded justification for the belief that Englishmen are eminently qualified for the administration of affairs in any part of the world, and on behalf of any nation. During the 24 years in which my noble friend has been at the head of Egyptian administration, he has done a work of infinite difficulty and of the highest importance-a work beneficial to the people of that country, bringing order out of chaos and laying firm and solid the foundation of a prosperity calculated to confer much honour upon the British name. To most of us here, and to many outside the House, Lord Cromer's name is chiefly connected with the great work which he has done in Egypt, but it would be a great mistake to suppose that his services have been entirely confined to that country. Lord Cromer was trained in a good school of administration. He was private secretary to my noble friend the late Lord Northbrook, and I had the advantage of having Lord Cromer as a financial member of the Indian Council during the chief part of the time that I had the honour to fill the office of Viceroy of India, I was able then to watch, from day to day, his devotion to duty, his firm grasp of financial principles, and his high administrative ability. It is, therefore, with no hesitation that I submit to. you a resolution, and ask you to express to the Sovereign your readiness to concur in doing an honoor to one who has rendered services alike to the Crown and the people of this country (hear. hear). A recognition such as that which it is intended to be offered to Lord Cromer has very generally been confined to members of the naval and military services, but I rejoice that upon this occasion, we are about to concur in conferring a similar honor upon one whose services have been of a civil nature. I think that we shall do well if we do not hesitate to place Lord Cromer in the same position and on perfect equality with the eminent soldiers and sailors who have been honoured in this way, I therefore beg to.move :- "That an humble address of concurrence and thanks be addressed to his Majesty in answer to his most gracious message" (cheers). The Marquess of lansdowne.-We, on this side of the House, do not yield to noble lords opposite in our appreciation of Lord Cromer's services, and we desire to associate ourselves with all that has been said by the noble marquess, and to accept our full share of responsibility for the proposal which the Government has made. Lord Cromer has, indeed, conferred signal services upon this country, and upon the Empire. I was glad that the noble marquess reminded us that, although we are apt to connect Lord Cromer's name almost exclusively with Egypt, it was not in Egypt alone that Lord Cromer did good work for his country. I can well remember the reputation which Lord Cromer left behind him in India as financial member of the Council but it is upon Egypt that Lord Cromer has left an indelible mark, and it is the affairs of Egypt which have ennabled him to write a page in the history of this country which is all his own. On such an occasion as this one is apt to look for a parallel, but I really believe there is no case which stands exactly on all fours with that-.of Lord Cromer. Our position in Egypt is an altogether exceptional position, and Lord Cromer's position in that country was also exceptional. I think that it would be almost true to say of him that during his long term of office he was able to serve two masters with equal fidelity and success. Of British interests he was a watchful custodian. Nobody need be reininded of the nature of British interests in Egypt. It is due to Lord Cromer that our position in that country, at one time undefined, and, indeed, somewhat precarious, became assured and consolidated.

div.head: MARVELLOUS ACHIEVEMENT IN EGYPT.
div.p: But if Lord Cromer was the faithful guardian of British interests he was not a less faithful guardian of the interests of the country committed to his charge. Nothing could have been more whole hearted than his devotion to Egyptian interests, and his work, when one comes to review it, was, indeed, a marvellous achievement in the interests of Egypt We see how, under his guidance, the great natural resources of that country were developed, and when we consider the manner in which he was able place its finances upon a sound footing; when we remember how every branch of Egyptian administration has, during his tenure of office, been put upon a sounder footing, we may indeed claim for him that, under the geidanoe of no other man, could so much have been done for the people of Egypt I daresay many of your lordships may have, from time to time, perused those admirable reports which every year Lord Cromer was in the habit of submitting to the Foreign Office. I have never read them without profound admiration and without feeling that this country might indeed be prond that we had such a man as Lord Cromer to represent us in other ports of the world. But although the public generally has been well aware of the magnitude of Lord Cromer's achievements, although it has, so to speak, seen the great output of work of which he was the author, it was reserved for those behind the scenes, who know the conditions under which that work was performed, to know in the face of what great difficulties, in the face of what apparently insuperable obstacles that task was so admirably accomplished. Lord Cromer had to contend with many disappointments; he had to overcome many rivalries, but he triumphed over them all, because he possessed in the highest degree two great qualities indispensable in a public man-the qualities of tact and tenacity. It would be unjust to Lord Cromer if I did not refer to my conviction that the satisfactory understanding obtained by the late Government with France in regard to many outstanding questions and notably with regard to Egyptian affairs, would not have been obtainable, or, at all events, attainable upon so satisfactory a basis, if it had not been for the exceptional position which Lord Cromer occupied among the representatives of the other Great Powers in Egypt In this House, at any rate, I am sure that no discordant note will be raised whan we consider the proposal laid before us by the noble Marquees (hear, hear). We feel that this proposed grant is no excessive reward for those great public services, and we trust that it may enable Lord Cromer to enjoy the well earned rest which we hope he will take after the labours which it is well known have involved every serious strain upon his health. We trust that he may live long to see others carry out the great work which will always be associated with his name (cheers). The motion was then agreed to.

div.head:
IN THE COMMONS.
PREMIER'S WARM TRIBUTE.
div.p: There was a very large attendance when the Premier, Sir Henry Campbell BanDerman, opened the debate in the House of Commons Hebsaid :- Hitherto such grants have, with some exceptions, been confined to those who have performed conspicuous service to the country in war, but I do not imagine that in this House of Commons there will be many who would wish to exclude from tangible acknowledgment the quieter and less resounding, but not less useful or lees deserving services of pacific administration (hear hear). It would not be too much to say that of all our pacific administrators throughout the Empire of the present. day, Lord Cromer is the foremost man-foremost in courage, wisdom, resource, and patience, and foremost, too, by the splendid results he has obtained (hear, hear). It is not in Egypt only that he has done great service. Before his career there commenced be had done work in India the effect of which is felt to this day. We all know how. Lord Cromer's administration of the affairs of Egypt has been marked by striking material progress, but his countrymen are even prouder of the security and liberty which his labour secured-of the revival of justice and work he did for education. When we reflect that 24 years ago, when he began this task, Egypt was bankrupt, and almost effaced under the burden of taxation and indebtedness, and that all his efforts for .reform had to be carried out under a system surely the most grievous to be borne that ever hampered an administrator, it is difficult to find words in which to express the admiration we feel for his steadfastness and courage.

div.head: REGENERATION OF EGYPT
div.p: Lord Cromer belongs to the school that holds it wise to hasten slowly if superimposing the civilisation of one race upon another. He profoundly disbelieved in any attempt to force the Egyptian people into Western mould. If he had cared to dazzle the world with swift and sensational results, there were plenty, of capitalists ready to go up and develop Egypt on the lines of European finance, and Lord Cromer would have saved himself infinite trouble if he had accepted their assistance and yielded to pressure and let them in. But he saw that the regeneration of Egypt could only be effected through the Egyptians themselves, and in devising measures for the emancipation of the peasantry from the bondage of debt and preserving them in their holdings, he laid the foundation of an agrarian policy which is the foundation of the future Egypt. That policy, entitles him to the gratitude of the country he has served so well, and to the admiration and respect of his countrymen. In losing him we lose a public servant who in all the anxious and harassing events and complications associated with Egypt has been a tower of strength, and whose courage, resource and wisdom, and loyalty have never failed. Now that he hs come home broken in health, having spent his strength and his fortune in the public service (hear, hear), I believe that, in showing him this mark of esteem, we shall not only be honouring a great man who has greatly served his country, but we shall he enabling the country and the Empire through this House, to recognise, as they desire, the debt they owe to Lord Cromer (cheers).

div.head: MR. BALFOUR'S TESTIMONY
div.p: Mr. Balfour (U., City of London) - My friends and I are anxious to give the government wholehearted support in the course they are pursueing (hear, hear) - a course which is consistent with the honour of the country and with .the traditions of the House (cheers). This is the first time, so far as I know, that the House of Commons has been asked to vote to a civil servant any great mark of national gratitude, But Lord Cromer belongs to a different class from that of other civil servants, however distinguished their services. We have before us in Egypt the fruits of the work of one great men. It stands out as isolated and singular a work of genius as the more sudden glories of some great military triumph, and, is separated from the ordinary work of even the greatest of the great race of civil servants abroad who have done such inestimable service to the British Empire by special charicteristics which mark it off and render it matter for differential treatment (cheers). Within a quarter of a century Lord Cromer has raised Egypt from the lowest pitch of social and economic degradation until it now stands among Oriental nations, I believe, absolutely alone in its prosperity. Everything he has touched he has succeeded in. Every cause he has taken in hand he has furthered. He leaves Egypt able to look back upon an administration longer, more beneficent, and more fruitful than, perhaps, can be boasted by any one of those great predecessors who have carried out great civilising work among races who have not risen to the level of those whose lot it has been to govern them. The difficulty of governing races in these conditions is great, and requires sympathy, courage, and steadfastness. Lord Cromer has all these qualities. He has dealt successfully with diplomatic and social difficulties in a manner which has earned the permanent gratitude of the Egyptian people, and which is well deserving of some distinguished mark of the gratitnde which this House and the country owe to one of the greatest of their servants (cheers).

div.head: THE HOME PRESS ON THE GRANT.
div.p: The press at home is unanimous in approving the grant to the Earl of Cromer, and refers in glowing terms to his splendid work in Egypt We append a few excerpts : "Times" We have lavished rewards upon the sailors and the soldiers who have led our fleets and our armies to victory, but no exact precedent has been found for the acknowledgment, by a grant of public moneys, of such inestimable services to England as Lord Cromer has rendered her. The grant to Sir Rowland Hill was the nearest case which could be discovered, but the resemblance between the circumstances in which it was made and those of the present vote is not very close. Lord Ripon said that, had no precedent existed, he should have been glad to create one, and, in effect, that is what the Government have done. We congratulate them upon their action and upon its exceptional timeliness. It is meet and wise that a nation such as ours should pay homage to splendid achievements in other fields than in the field of war. They demand gifts not less rare, labours as arduous and more prolonged, and courage equally high. At a time when the mind of the whole world is. bent on furthering the cause of peace, it is particularly becoming that the nation which has so often proclaimed its zeal for that cause should bestow a signal mark of its favour upon a statesman whose life work has been a work of peace. Lord Lansdowne, who followed the leader of the House, called to mind tho difficulties and the obstacles under which that work was accomplished. The greatness of the felicitations of the whole world. Lord Cromer's character lies in this, that, whatever secret cares and anxieties they laid upon him, he never suffered them to divert his course from the goal he had set himself to reach. It has been his happiness to reach that goal amidst the felicitations of the whole world. It remained for his Sovereign and his countrymen to confer upon him a material token of the deep appreciation they entertain of his achievements, and they have discharged this duty to themselfes and to him by the vote of last night. The work, which Lord Cromer has done is there for all the world to see; all the world has looked upon it, and has declared with one accord that it is good.
"DAILY TELEGRAPH"

There have been few periods within the last thirty years at which Lord Cromer could not have honourably enriched himself by quitting the responsible post in the occupation of which he did such invaluable work, both for the Empire and for the people of Egypt. As a reward for his great services the sum of fifty thousand pounds is but paltry, though it is understood that it represents the maximum the great Proconsul would accept Lord Cromer will value far more than this provision for his retirement the tributes paid to his achievements by the representatives of both the great parties in the State, who alone could appreciate them at their full value. It was a happy incident that the two leaders in the House of Lords, Lord Ripon and Lord Lansdownes, should have been in a position to bear testimony to Lord Cromer's work in India, before he had been transferred to the fuel in which he won his proudest laurels.
"TRIBUNE

In conferring a signal honour upon Lord Cromer Parliament has been truly representitive of a grateful nation. The system of presenting testimonials upon their retirement to men who have done good work and earned general esteem has, perhaps, shown signs of brief rather overdone in many minor spheres of British life; it may have become a little too like a matter of course that the clock or the service of plate or purse shall be the natural sequel of a long spell of parish work or the smoothly successful discharge of business duties. But it is not so at the top, in the big affairs of the Empire. There the grant is a rare event, reserved for extraordinary services. Lord Cromer is one of the very few who have had the opportunity to do conspicuously extraordinary work on the peaceful side, and of the still fewer who have surpassed all expectations and confounded all apparent probabilities by the manner in which such opportunity has been grasped. He has done not a little for the peace of the whole world, since, as was well said last night, his Egyptian career undoubtedly helped to make possible the cleaning of the slate as between England and France, and warm friendship now established.
"DAILY CHRONICLE"

Lord Cromer's powers of mind and character were singularly adapted to the conditions in which Egypt stood for many years after he took office. If the conditions have changed, the change is chiefly due to his own high services, and it would be absurdly unfair to make light of what he has done because the prosperity which he has produced may call for an advance in the methods of government.
"DAILY NEWS"

Among all tho great servants of the Empire, Lord Croinet holds a very special position, lie has by universal admission achieved successes which twenty three years ago would have seemed impossible. lie has extricated the. finances of tlie State from the confusion and lespnir in which -lie found them. He has rescued tho peasants from oppression end overwhelming taxation. He Iras introduced order and justice into public life. He has worked wonders In engineering and irrigation. Not least pf his claims to public gratitude is tlie strong hand with which he has defended Egypt from the private avarice and the finan- cial conspiracies which have made up so much of tho history of Imperialism elsewhere. Such a career stands out conspicuously in tho ad- ministrative successes of a nation that ii not poor in the records of honest and public-spirited government

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Après une ouverture ferme, le march*) a un peu réàctionné pour reprendre en fin de séance et clôturer sensiblement nu môme niveau qu'hier. Comme d'habitude les affaires ont été en général elairsemées. 'Devant l'impuissance des haussiers h déterminer une hausse rapide et suivie, il faut bien reconnaître que les ven- deurs existent mais que, retenus par l'espé- rance de plus hauts prix en présence du mon vomont actuel, ils attendent une accentuation de la reprise pour se défaire de leur stock à des conditions moins désavantageuses. (/qel- ques acheteurs se présentent occasionnelle mont, et c'est là toute ^'explication d'une corbeille en apjiarenee Imimnière mais tpii n'achète que fort peu. En ce qui concerne l'allure dés valeurs égyptiennes sur les marchés européens elle ert moins bonne, sans compter que le taux d'es- compte hausse encore de 1/8 à 3 7/8. Cela n'a d'ailleurs que médiocrement im- pressionné notre place, puisque l'Agricole s'a- vance de 8 1/8 vendeurs à 8 1/8 acheteurs et la National Bank de 20 à 20 1/4 vendeurs. div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT

LIVERPOOL, August 1. The demand ou the Spot for Egyptian continues very quiet, but prices keep fairly steady and quotations are unchanges on the week. In Futures a small business has resulted; the following are the latest quotations :- Aug. 10.43 Nov. 10:41 Fob. 10.31 Sep. 10.45 Dec. 10.35 .Mar. 10 31 Oct 10.43 Jau. 10.32 American Futures. The Market this week has again been very quiet in tone, with only a very limited business doing outside of the professional trading. There have been frequent moderate fluctuations and to-day's prices are 7^ @ 8 points higher for the Current, month and August, Septemher delivery, and 8J @ 4 points higher for the other positions, than those of last Thursday. The slight improvement is more due to a certain sensitiveness about the real condition of the Crop, because more or less the weather has continued dry with high temperatures. There is not apparently so far any serious anxiety, but there is anxiety of a kind. We are also awaiting with considerable interest the Bureau report to be issued in New York to-morrow after our market is closed, and as Liverpool does not reopen until Tuesdayy the 6th inst, there is a general squaring up of accounts. The latest values are, delivery :- Aug. 6.89 Nov./Dro. 6.551 M*r./ApL 6.6S Aug./Sep. 6.77 Dec./Jan 6.54J Aprit/May 0.56 Hept./Oct. 6.64 .lan./Feb. 6SXJ May/.Iune 9.67 Oct/Nov. 6.581 FeU/Mar. 6.51

div.head:
THE CASABLANCA TROUBLE
FRANCES NOTE TO THE POWERS
FRENCH LEGION EN ROUTE

div.p: The representatives of France have notified the various powers who signed the Act of Algesiras, of the growing necessity of organising the police in the Morocco ports, affirming that France is resolutely determined to maintain the authority of the Sultan, and the integrity of the empire, to assure of commercial transactions, the punishment of the authors of the massacres, and the organisation of the Casablanca police in accordance with Spain. (Havas)

The cruisers "Gloire," "Coude," "Jeanne il Arc," and "Gueydon" and two companies of the Foreign Legion have left Oran for Casablanca. The French representatives have handed to the signatories of the Act of Algeciras a declaration declaring that events in Morocco had outstripped the contemplated measures, and reaffirming the intention of France to maintain the authority of the Sultan and the indépendance of Morocco. Casablanca would be policed in conjunction with Spain. (Reuter)

It appears that the "Galilée" landed 60 bluejackets at the request of the Consul and in concurrence with the Bashaw. They were proceeding to the Consulate when they were tired upon by Moors whom they repulsed with the bayonet. The "Galilée" and "Du t'hayla" then bombarded the Moorish quarter and tribesmen on the beach with melinite. (Reuter)

The city was occupied by troops this morning. Strong patrols were posted. Companies of the 4th Middlesex, Sussex, and Essex Regiments were subsequently marched to their positions watched by hundreds of citizens. (R)

It is understood that Great Britain has agreed to withdraw the urgency clause from the limitation of armamanets proposal, merely declaring the examination of the question as highly desirable. (Reuter)
Prince Ferman Firma has been appointed Governor of Azer Baijan and has been hastily sent to Tabriz owing to the Turkish incursion. (Reuter)

The Government has decided to lay down during 1907? two battleships of a new type, evolved by the Ministry of Marine, of 19,970 tons, armed with ten l2-inch guns and fitted with turbine engines; their speed will be 21 knots. (Reuter)

The Tsar and Emperor William exchanged toasts at a farewell luncheon on board the "Standard.'' The Emperor said that he hoped the Tzar would be permitted to accomplish the construction of his fleet.(Reuter)

div.head: SLEEPING SICKNESS EXPEDITION.
SUCCESSFUL EXPERIMENTS ON CATTLE.
div.p: The president of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, Sir Alfred Jones, has received the following telegram from the sleeping sickness expedition of the school, which was sent to Africa early in May last:- "Send quantity atoxyl immediately. Cattle experiments indicate success. Montgomery Trypanosomiasis Expedition, Broken Hill, N.W. Rhodesia." Atoxyl is the name of the remedy recommended for therapeutical treatment in cases of sleeping sickness. The sleeping sickness expedition arrivod at Kolomo on June 10, where they were the guests of Mr. Codrington, the Administrator, who gave every facility for their work. At the end of the present month it is intended that Dr. Kinghorn, one of the members of the expedition, shall proceed direct to Fort Jameson. Mr. Montgomery, the other member, will go west to the River Kafne, and up that river towards the Congo. He will then strike across the country, and meet Dr. Kinghorn on the river Luapaln about November, traversing the whole of the time a territory infested by the T'se T'se fly. One of the main objects of the expedition, which is financed by the Liverpool School and supported by the British protectorates concerned and the British South African Company, is to endeavour to prevent the spread of sleeping sickness into districts hitherto uninfested. The expedition will also study the disease on the spot, and will pay special attention to the disease of animals and the distribution of biting flies. It is the fourth expedition of the Liverpool School that has been sent to Africa to study trypanosomiasis.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market

It is stated on very good authority that the Egyptian Government has this week been a heavy seller of Consols, the object being to strengthen the position of the National Bank. This is a commendable policy, and satisfactory as showing that the banks are beginning early to make preparatives for obtaining gold at the lowest possible price, in order to be ready for the heavy autumn demand incidental to the moving of the coming cotton crop. It is impossible to estimate at the present moment the probable requirements for this purpose, but all the imports from the cotton fields foreshadow a splendid crop, so that the total imports of gold will necessarily amount to a large figure, as we have said before, we have no doubt that all the necessary accommodation will be obtained without serious inconvenience to the money market. Several causes have contributed to the heavy Call in the reserve reported this week, the chief of these being demands for cash in connection with the holidays and end of month requirements. The imports of gold from abroad amounted to £259,000, but £862,000 in coin and £572,000 in notes went into circulation, with the result that The reserve shows a decline of £1,181,667, at £24,867,412. This compares with last year's total of £24,629,000. The proportion to liabilities is 3/8 per cent lower on the week at 46 3/4 per cent, the proportion at this period last year being 47.41 per oent The discount market is firm, and three months bills were yesterday quoted 8, 11/16 to 3 3/4 per cent In consequence of a large order from this Continent, the price of bar gold has risen 7/8d. to 77/10 1/8.
Silver
During the greater part of the week the silver market remained quiet, but strong buying yesterday sent the price up to 32, 1/16, the highest figure touched for five months.
The Stock Market

Business on the Stock Exchange has become so scarce of late that many members concluded this week that their time would be much more profitably spent on the moor or by the sea, and the consequence has been that during the past two or three days the "House" has had a somewhat deserted appearance. Idleness has prevailed in most sections, and the tone has been anything but satisfactory. It is gratifying to note, however that the Egyptian section has been firm and that an appreciable amount of investment buying has been going on. This bears out what we said last week, that the leading brokers are taking an optimistic view of the trade troubles connected with the crisis. The announcement that the assets of Messrs Salmi Brothers were considerably in excess of the liabilities has had a reassuring effect, and it is believed that in the case of Messrs Harriraan Brothers, whose creditors meet next Wednesday the liabilities will not prove to be heavy. Consols continue the most surprising feature olfmarkets, and it is quite within the bounds of possibility that before the next settlement they will be down to 80. Large quantities of the stock were delivered at the settlement this week, and heavy buying on behalf of the Government has totally failed to assist the market.
Consols

The premier security on Monday declined to 82 5/8, the lowest price touched for over half a century. On Tuesday and Wednesday the market was firmer, but yesterday there was a further loss of 3/8, the closing quotations being 82 5/8 for cash and 82, 18/16 for the account To-day Consols have improved 1/16 for the account
Foreign Bonds

In the international market, the feature has been the weakness of the older Japanese issues. A further decline of 1/4 yesterday put the 4 1/2 per cents, down to 93 1/4 and 89 7/8 respectively, while the Pours were quoted 83. Russians have also been sold, and the Fives relapsed to 83 3/4, the Fours being down to 78 7/8. To-day Japanese have been irregular the new Fours have shed 1/4, but two other issues are 1/8 better.
Home Ralls

The home railway market has been very flat, and prices have given way heavily in spite of good traffics and excellent holiday prospects. The labour agitation is exercising a depressing effect, as investors refuse to have anything to do with these shares in the present state of unrest The directors of the railways are adopting a firm attitude, which if pursued must result in the employes moderating their demands. The possibility of a strike Is remote, as the railwaymens' union represents only a small section of the total employes. The Scotch shares Beem to be the only steady points. Yesterday Caledonian Preference advanced 1, and North British Preference 1/2, but most of the heavies declined 1/2 to 1. Home rails show some recovery to-day. There are several gains of ¼ to ½.
Americans.

Shares in the American railway section have moved rather irregularly, Wall Street having been pessimistic regarding the future outlook. Yesterday the market here was affected by uncertainty over the Pacific dividends, and during the morning there was considerable selling of the leading shares. Later the tone became firmer. In the "Street" it was announced that the Southern Pacific dividend had been declared at the rate of 6 per cent as against the previous distribution of 5 per cent, but that no action has been taken with regard to the Union Pacific dividend. The news seemed to have been fully discounted. Southern Pacific fell to 90 1/2, closing at 91 1/8, while Unions left off at 145 5/8, alter being 145 1/4. The tone in Americana has been better to-day. Unions have advanced 1/4.
Egyptians

Daring the greater part of the week prices in the Egyptian market have been good, and there has been a fairly general advance all- round. The tone eased off a little yesterday, but this is explained by the sparsity of business. National Bank have been up to 201, closing tonight 19 5/8-7/8, and Agricultural Bank, after beiug 8 1/4, close 8 1/16 8/16, but these prices are well up on balance. Daira Sanieh, which have been fairly largely dealt in, were quoted yesterday ex dividend, the Ordinary being 12 7/8 - 13 1/8 ex 25/-s., and the Deferred 65- 70 ex £10. Delta Land & Investment after changing hands at 2, are easiet at 1 7/8 offered, but Egyptian Estates are firmer since the meeting at 5/8-3/4 Salt and Soda and Egyptian Markets have been scarcely mentioned, closing unchanged at 13/16 and 1 3/8 respectively. Union Foncier close 4 1/2 -3/4, and Khédivial Mail Ordinary are much letter at 22/6-23/6. United Egyptian Lands are firmer at 3/8 - 1/3 and Corporation of Westen Egypt are steady at 7/16-9/16. Anglrt-Egyptian Bank are still dull at 12 5/8 - 7/8, but Land Banks are firm at 7-1/4.
Mining.

Liquidation from Paris has caused mining shares to be dull, and the market has also suffered, in common with other sections, from lack of business. De Beers were down to 22 3/4, a fall on the day of 5/16, while Premier were no better than 9 S.S. at which they showed a loss of 1/4. Modderfontein gave way 1/8 to 4 7/8, and Tanganyika 3/16 to 4, 7/16. To-day mines have been idle Egyptian Mining shares are unmentioned, and prices show practically no chage on the week.

div.head: A Dramatic Event
Popular Actress cured by Dr. Williams Pink Pills.
The Victim of Nerve Troubles, Indigestion and Languorall other Medicines had proved Useless
div.p: Incidents in the careers of well-known people are of special interest to the public ; recognising this a representative waited upon Miss Amy Corallie at the Métropole Theatre, Birmingham, to gather some details of her career. Miss Corallie - in private life Mrs. Finlay- is twenty-four, and has been before the footlights since childhood. "Yes, I can spare a few minutes," she said ; "time enough to tell of the good I derived from Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. "I have had the honour of appearing before Royalty, and the late J. L. Toole often complimented me upon my stage work ; yet for a long time I was acting under a positive prosecution. Sharp pains in my back dragged me down ; sometimes I went to the theatre feeling more dead than alive, with scarcely enough strength to drag one leg after the other. My blood felt chilled ; rheumatic pains flew all over me, and my limbs became almost useless. "I struggled against these ailments, but it was of little use. My face grew pallid, and I felt entirely worn out, yet all night long I scarcely closed my eyes in sleep. I lost all vitality, and felt depressed and weary, while my memory failed. Food upset me, and I always had a nasty taste in my mouth. "Friends noticed the change in me, for at the least exertion I gasped for breath and my heart throbbed. Often I have returned to the dressing room fainting and exhausted. Every noise got on my nerves, and made me tremble from head to foot. "I took so many medicines that my digestion was quite upset. Then fortunately I accepted the advice of a friend, and tried Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. Relief followed, and so I continued with these pilla Then I improved rapidly, and soon could enjoy meals without being tormented by indigestion. "My blood was nourished, and a healthy colour returned. I felt more energetic in every way. My memory was clear. I was quite a new woman in a few weeks after taking Dr Williams' Pink Pills, never really tired, blessed with a healthy appetite, and able to sleep well at night In my opinion Dr. Williams' Pink Pills build up the brain as well as the body, blood and nerves." When the Blood becomes thin and weak the system rapidly breaks down. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People make Good, Rich Blood and feed the starved nerves. They hare cured Anaemia, General Weakness, Influenza's After-Effects Indigestion, Eczema, Rheumatism, Sciatica, St Vitas' Dance, Nervous Disorders, Paralysis and Ladies' Ailments. Sold by all dealers, but insist on having the genuine pills, for substitutes never cure. Sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 18 the box and P.T. 70 for six boxes.
